title: Ezekiel Chapter 47 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 47 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 47 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 47.

questions.question: From which direction did the waters issue out from under the threshold of the house?
options: East
West
North
South
questions.correctAnswer: East
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:1 states that the waters issued out from under the threshold of the house eastward.

questions.question: How deep were the waters when the man led Ezekiel through the first thousand cubits?
options: To the ankles
To the knees
To the loins
To the waist
questions.correctAnswer: To the ankles
questions.explanation: According to Ezekiel 47:3, the waters were to the ankles after the first thousand cubits.

questions.question: What happens to the waters after measuring four thousand cubits?
options: They become a river too deep to cross
They dry up completely
They turn into mud
They overflow the land
questions.correctAnswer: They become a river too deep to cross
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:5 explains that after measuring four thousand cubits, the waters become a river that could not be passed over.

questions.question: What grows on both sides of the riverbank?
options: Very many trees
Desert shrubs
No vegetation
Rocks and stones
questions.correctAnswer: Very many trees
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:7 mentions that very many trees were on the one side and on the other bank of the river.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 47:9, what will happen wherever the river flows?
options: Everything that lives will live
The land will become desert
The water will turn salty
No life will be found
questions.correctAnswer: Everything that lives will live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:9 states that everything that lives and moves where the river flows will live.

questions.question: From where to where will the fishers stand to spread their nets?
options: From Engedi to Eneglaim
From Jerusalem to Bethlehem
From Egypt to Babylon
From Nineveh to Tyre
questions.correctAnswer: From Engedi to Eneglaim
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:10 says fishers shall stand from Engedi even unto Eneglaim to spread their nets.

questions.question: What will happen to the miry places and marshes according to Ezekiel 47:11?
options: They shall not be healed and shall be given to salt
They will become fertile fields
They will be filled with fish
They will be covered with trees
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be healed and shall be given to salt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:11 states that miry places and marshes shall not be healed but given to salt.

questions.question: What benefit do the trees by the river provide?
options: Food and medicine
Only shade
Wood for building
No benefit
questions.correctAnswer: Food and medicine
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:12 explains that the trees produce fruit for food and leaves for medicine.

questions.question: How many portions will Joseph have of the land inheritance?
options: Two portions
One portion
Three portions
No portion
questions.correctAnswer: Two portions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:13 says Joseph shall have two portions of the land.

questions.question: Which side of the land is described as extending from the great sea to the way of Hethlon?
options: North side
South side
East side
West side
questions.correctAnswer: North side
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:15 describes the northern border of the land from the great sea to the way of Hethlon.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 47:22 states that strangers who sojourn among Israel will have no inheritance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:22 states strangers who sojourn and have children among Israel shall have inheritance among the tribes.

questions.question: True or False: The waters flow into the desert and then into the sea where they are healed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:8 states the waters flow toward the east country into the desert and then into the sea where they shall be healed.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 47:4 mentions waters rising to the shoulders after the second measurement.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:4 describes waters rising to the knees after the second thousand cubits, not shoulders.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ezekiel 47:1: '...waters issued out from under the ______ of the house eastward.'
options: threshold
window
door
roof
questions.correctAnswer: threshold
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:1 states waters issued out from under the threshold of the house eastward.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 47:12: '...the fruit thereof shall be for ______, and the leaf thereof for medicine.'
options: meat
wine
oil
bread
questions.correctAnswer: meat
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:12 says the fruit shall be for meat and the leaf for medicine.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 47 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 47 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezekiel 47:1-5, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and faith?
options: Faith grows as we move deeper into God's presence, like the increasing depth of the water.
Trials will always be shallow and easy to overcome.
God expects us to avoid difficulties rather than face them.
The deeper the water, the less God cares about us.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith grows as we move deeper into God's presence, like the increasing depth of the water.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:1-5 describes waters that increase from ankle to knee to loins to a river too deep to cross, symbolizing how faith and trust in God deepen as we remain close to Him through trials. This teaches perseverance and growing reliance on God.

questions.question: How does the vision of the river bringing life to trees in Ezekiel 47:7-12 teach about the power of God's Word in personal devotion?
options: God's Word nourishes and sustains spiritual life like water does trees.
Spiritual growth is independent of God's provision.
Trees only grow with human effort, not divine intervention.
God's Word is mainly for judgment, not growth.
questions.correctAnswer: God's Word nourishes and sustains spiritual life like water does trees.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:7-12 shows water bringing life to trees whose leaves and fruit do not fade, symbolizing how God's Word sustains and renews believers through ongoing devotion and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive a neighbor. Based on Ezekiel 47:9, what biblical truth about restoration would you share?
options: Where God's presence flows, all things are healed and restored, including relationships.
Forgiveness is optional in the Christian life.
Restoration is only possible for some, not all.
God only restores physical health, not relationships.
questions.correctAnswer: Where God's presence flows, all things are healed and restored, including relationships.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:9 emphasizes that everything living where the river flows will live and be healed, illustrating God's power to heal and restore broken relationships like forgiveness demands.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 47:10 teach about the blessing of generosity and stewardship in daily life?
options: God blesses the diligent and generous, like fishers who catch abundant fish where the river flows.
Generosity leads to scarcity and hardship.
Stewardship is irrelevant to God’s blessings.
Blessings come only from luck, not faithful stewardship.
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses the diligent and generous, like fishers who catch abundant fish where the river flows.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:10 describes fishers standing on the riverbanks with abundant catches, symbolizing how faithful stewardship and generosity lead to God’s provision and blessing in life.

questions.question: A new believer asks about the importance of integrity and honesty at work. How does the vision of dividing land by lot in Ezekiel 47:21-23 relate to this?
options: God values fairness and integrity, as shown by the equal land inheritance by lot.
Dishonesty is acceptable if it benefits you.
Integrity is unimportant in daily work.
Inheritance should be taken by force rather than fairness.
questions.correctAnswer: God values fairness and integrity, as shown by the equal land inheritance by lot.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:21-23 shows land being divided fairly by lot among tribes and strangers, highlighting God's call for honesty and integrity in dealings, including work and stewardship.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 47:8 emphasize the importance of evangelism and sharing the gospel in Christian life?
options: God’s healing waters flowing to the sea symbolize the gospel reaching all nations.
Evangelism is optional for believers.
The gospel should only be shared locally, not broadly.
God’s healing is only for a select few.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s healing waters flowing to the sea symbolize the gospel reaching all nations.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:8 describes waters flowing eastward into the desert and the sea where they bring healing, symbolizing the spreading of the gospel to all people for spiritual healing and life.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and contentment can be learned from the description of the river that could not be crossed in Ezekiel 47:5?
options: Recognize our limitations and trust God’s provision rather than relying on our own strength.
We should pridefully overcome every obstacle ourselves.
Contentment comes from ignoring challenges.
Humility means avoiding responsibility.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize our limitations and trust God’s provision rather than relying on our own strength.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:5 describes a river too deep to cross, teaching believers to humbly acknowledge limits and rely on God’s power and provision in life’s challenges.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 47:12, the fruit of the trees by the river is never consumed and provides healing leaves, symbolizing God's continual provision and care.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:12 states the leaves do not fade and the fruit is for food, the leaves for medicine, illustrating God’s ongoing care and provision for spiritual and physical needs.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 47:11 teaches that all parts of the land will be healed and fruitful without exception.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:11 specifies that miry places and marshes will not be healed but will be left salt, showing not everything will be restored, which calls for realistic hope and faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 47:13 teaches that the land inheritance shall be divided according to the __________ tribes of Israel.
options: twelve
ten
seven
five
questions.correctAnswer: twelve
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:13 states the land is to be inherited by the twelve tribes of Israel, emphasizing God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 47:22-23 instruct us about the Christian attitude towards strangers and newcomers in the community?
options: Strangers who live among believers are to be treated as native-born and receive inheritance.
Strangers should be excluded from blessings.
Newcomers are to earn blessings through works only.
Inheritance is reserved only for original members.
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers who live among believers are to be treated as native-born and receive inheritance.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:22-23 teaches inclusion and generosity by giving strangers inheritance as if they were born among the tribes, reflecting godly love and fellowship.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in marriage and family life. What lesson from Ezekiel 47:12 might you share?
options: God’s provision is continuous and renewing, like the trees that bear fruit every month.
Family life should be perfect without struggles.
Provision depends solely on human effort.
Fruitfulness is irrelevant to family life.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s provision is continuous and renewing, like the trees that bear fruit every month.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:12 describes trees whose fruit does not fail and is produced monthly, symbolizing God’s faithful and ongoing provision, encouraging contentment in family life.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 47:6-7 encourage believers facing discouragement in their service to others and church life?
options: God’s presence brings life and fruitfulness even when it seems unseen, like many trees at the riverbank.
Discouragement means God has abandoned you.
Service is only valuable if immediately rewarded.
Church life is irrelevant to personal growth.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence brings life and fruitfulness even when it seems unseen, like many trees at the riverbank.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:6-7 shows that after returning to the riverbank, many trees are present, illustrating God’s unseen blessings and encouragement in faithful service.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 47:15-20 teach about stewardship and responsibility in managing resources within the community?
options: Clear boundaries and fair distribution reflect God’s order and responsibility in stewardship.
Resources should be taken without regard to fairness.
Stewardship is unimportant in community life.
Boundaries cause division and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Clear boundaries and fair distribution reflect God’s order and responsibility in stewardship.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:15-20 outlines precise borders for land inheritance, emphasizing God’s desire for order, fairness, and responsible stewardship of resources.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the river bringing life in Ezekiel 47 inspire a believer struggling with temptation and trials?
options: God’s life-giving presence sustains believers, empowering them to overcome trials.
Temptations are impossible to overcome.
Trials indicate God’s rejection.
Believers must rely only on their own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s life-giving presence sustains believers, empowering them to overcome trials.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47 portrays a river whose waters bring life and healing, symbolizing how God’s presence empowers believers to persevere and overcome temptation.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 47 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 47.

questions.question: What is the symbolic significance of the waters issuing from under the threshold of the house in Ezekiel 47:1?
options: They represent the Holy Spirit flowing from the presence of God
They symbolize the floodwaters of Noah’s time
They represent the river Jordan’s cleansing power
They are a symbol of the Nile River's fertility
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the Holy Spirit flowing from the presence of God
questions.explanation: The waters issuing from under the threshold symbolize life-giving water flowing from God’s sanctuary, which parallels the New Testament imagery of the Holy Spirit flowing from God’s presence (Ezekiel 47:1).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 47:3-5, the increasing depth of the water as the man leads Ezekiel eastward serves as a typological foreshadowing of what biblical theme?
options: The increasing presence and power of God’s salvation
The encroachment of Babylonian exile
The rising floodwaters of the Great Flood
The expansion of Israel’s territory
questions.correctAnswer: The increasing presence and power of God’s salvation
questions.explanation: The gradual increase in water depth from ankle to river deep enough to swim in symbolizes the expanding reach and power of God’s life-giving salvation, a theme evident throughout Scripture (Ezekiel 47:3-5).

questions.question: What is the significance of the river ultimately flowing into the sea and healing the waters, as described in Ezekiel 47:8?
options: It symbolizes restoration and renewal of formerly desolate places
It represents the destruction of all enemies
It signifies the permanent separation of Israel from foreign nations
It illustrates the drying up of the Mediterranean Sea
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes restoration and renewal of formerly desolate places
questions.explanation: The healing of the sea by the river’s waters portrays divine restoration, turning barren places into thriving life sources, which echoes other prophetic themes of restoration (Ezekiel 47:8).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 47:9, what consequence does the river’s coming have on living creatures?
options: Every living thing that moves where the river flows will live
Only birds will thrive by the river
Fish will perish because of polluted waters
The river will cause drought in surrounding lands
questions.correctAnswer: Every living thing that moves where the river flows will live
questions.explanation: The text explicitly states that all living creatures in the river will live, emphasizing the life-giving and restorative nature of the waters (Ezekiel 47:9).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 47:12, what is the significance of the trees growing on both sides of the river whose leaves do not fade and whose fruit is for food and medicine?
options: They symbolize eternal life and divine provision
They represent the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil
They foreshadow the destruction of Jerusalem
They indicate the presence of pagan worship
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize eternal life and divine provision
questions.explanation: The trees whose leaves do not fade and fruit that serves as medicine symbolize ongoing life and healing, paralleling eternal life themes found in Revelation 22 and other scriptures (Ezekiel 47:12).

questions.question: The division of land according to the twelve tribes of Israel in Ezekiel 47:13-23 is a restoration motif. How does this relate to earlier biblical covenants?
options: It reaffirms the promise God made to Abraham about inheriting land
It contradicts the covenant with David about kingship
It nullifies the Mosaic Law
It introduces a new covenant with no land promises
questions.correctAnswer: It reaffirms the promise God made to Abraham about inheriting land
questions.explanation: The division of land among the tribes recalls the Abrahamic covenant where God promised the land to his descendants, reinforcing continuity of God’s promises (Ezekiel 47:13-23).

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is reflected in the use of measuring and dividing land by lot as described in Ezekiel 47:21-23?
options: Allocating inheritance and property rights through divination or casting lots
Building ziggurats as territorial markers
Using astrology to determine kingship
Establishing temple tax zones
questions.correctAnswer: Allocating inheritance and property rights through divination or casting lots
questions.explanation: Casting lots was a common ancient practice for fairly distributing land or inheritance, aligning with Israel’s use of lots described here (Ezekiel 47:21-23).

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 47:11, all the marshy and miry places along the river will be healed and become fertile land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:11 clearly states that the miry and marshy places will not be healed but will be given to salt, indicating persistent barrenness.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in the description of the water’s depth increasing in increments (ankles, knees, loins) in Ezekiel 47:3-5?
options: Progressive parallelism
Chiasm
Metaphorical simile
Allegorical inversion
questions.correctAnswer: Progressive parallelism
questions.explanation: The increasing depths represent a progressive parallelism, where the incremental details build upon each other to emphasize the river’s growing power (Ezekiel 47:3-5).

questions.question: How does the river in Ezekiel 47 parallel the river described in the Garden of Eden in Genesis 2:10-14?
options: Both rivers issue from a sacred place and bring life to the surrounding land
Both rivers cause destruction through floods
Both rivers are used for ritual washing of priests
Both rivers symbolize human sin and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Both rivers issue from a sacred place and bring life to the surrounding land
questions.explanation: Ezekiel’s river, issuing from the temple, mirrors Eden’s river flowing from the garden, both symbolizing divine life-giving presence (Ezekiel 47:1; Genesis 2:10-14).

questions.question: What is the significance of the mention of Joseph receiving two portions of the land inheritance in Ezekiel 47:13?
options: It reflects Joseph’s tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh receiving separate allotments
It signifies Joseph’s exclusion from land inheritance
It indicates Joseph will receive double taxation
It is a metaphor for Joseph’s spiritual blessings only
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Joseph’s tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh receiving separate allotments
questions.explanation: Joseph’s double portion refers to his two sons’ tribes, Ephraim and Manasseh, each receiving a share of the land, consistent with earlier biblical tradition (Ezekiel 47:13).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the healing and life-giving waters imagery found in Ezekiel 47?
options: Revelation 22:1-2
John 3:16
Acts 2:1-4
Romans 8:28
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation 22:1-2
questions.explanation: Revelation 22 describes a river of life flowing from God’s throne with trees bearing fruit for healing, directly echoing Ezekiel 47’s imagery (Ezekiel 47:12; Revelation 22:1-2).

questions.question: What is the historical-cultural relevance of the cities mentioned in the border description of Ezekiel 47:15-17?
options: They represent known border landmarks from ancient Israelite geography
They are symbolic cities from Babylonian mythology
They were capitals of the Egyptian empire
They are fictional places created for prophetic vision
questions.correctAnswer: They represent known border landmarks from ancient Israelite geography
questions.explanation: The cities like Hamath, Damascus, and Zedad are real ancient Near Eastern locations marking Israel’s territorial boundaries, grounding the vision in historical geography (Ezekiel 47:15-17).

questions.question: Why does Ezekiel specify that strangers who sojourn among the tribes shall receive an inheritance within the tribe they live, as in Ezekiel 47:22-23?
options: To emphasize inclusion and integration within Israel’s restored community
To restrict foreigners from owning land
To prepare for future exile
To prioritize Levites over others
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize inclusion and integration within Israel’s restored community
questions.explanation: The passage shows an inclusive vision where foreigners who live among Israel and bear children are treated as native-born, emphasizing unity and restoration (Ezekiel 47:22-23).

questions.question: The phrase "waters shall be healed" (Ezekiel 47:8) uses the Hebrew root רָפָא (rapha). What is the broader biblical significance of this root word?
options: It denotes healing or restoration, often used for physical and spiritual healing
It refers to destruction or judgment
It means cleansing through fire
It implies separation or exile
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes healing or restoration, often used for physical and spiritual healing
questions.explanation: The Hebrew root רָפָא (rapha) commonly signifies healing or restoration, highlighting the restorative nature of the waters (Ezekiel 47:8).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 47 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 47 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of the waters issuing from under the threshold of the house eastward in Ezekiel's vision?
options: They symbolize the life-giving presence flowing from God's sanctuary
They represent a flood of judgment to destroy the land
They indicate a physical river for irrigation only
They show the retreat of God's presence from the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize the life-giving presence flowing from God's sanctuary
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:1-2 describes waters flowing from the temple threshold eastward, symbolizing the outflow of God's life and blessings. This aligns with John 7:38 where Jesus speaks of rivers of living water flowing from believers, and Psalm 36:8-9 where the river of God brings joy and life. Revelation 22:1-2 also depicts the river of life flowing from God's throne.

questions.question: How deep were the waters after the first measurement of a thousand cubits?
options: To the ankles
To the knees
To the loins
Too deep to cross
questions.correctAnswer: To the ankles
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:3 clearly states the waters were to the ankles after the first thousand cubits, indicating progressive increase in depth. This gradual increase symbolizes growing fullness of spiritual life, similar to progressive sanctification described in 2 Corinthians 3:18 and growth in grace in 2 Peter 3:18.

questions.question: What happens to the waters after the fourth measurement of a thousand cubits?
options: They become a river too deep to cross
They dry up completely
They overflow and flood the land
They remain ankle-deep
questions.correctAnswer: They become a river too deep to cross
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:5 states the waters become a river deep enough to swim in, symbolizing the overwhelming and unstoppable life-giving presence of God. This is reminiscent of Isaiah 43:2 where God promises protection through deep waters, and Revelation 22:1 where the river of life flows abundantly.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 47, what grows on both sides of the riverbank?
options: Very many trees
Thorns and briars
Desert shrubs
No vegetation
questions.correctAnswer: Very many trees
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:7 describes very many trees growing on both banks of the river, symbolizing fruitfulness and life. This imagery aligns with Psalm 1:3 where a righteous man is like a tree planted by rivers of water, bearing fruit in due season, and Revelation 22:2 where the tree of life grows by the river.

questions.question: What is the effect of the waters entering the sea, according to Ezekiel 47?
options: The waters shall be healed
The sea becomes salty and barren
The sea dries up
The sea overflows its banks
questions.correctAnswer: The waters shall be healed
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:8 teaches the waters entering the sea will heal it, symbolizing restoration and renewal. This healing reflects God’s redemptive work in creation (Psalm 104:30), and the hope of restoration in Isaiah 11:9 where the earth is full of the knowledge of the Lord.

questions.question: What is said about the fish in the river of Ezekiel's vision?
options: There will be a very great multitude of fish, all living where the river flows
Fish will be scarce due to pollution
Only a few fish will survive
Fish will be harmful creatures
questions.correctAnswer: There will be a very great multitude of fish, all living where the river flows
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:9 promises abundant fish where the river flows, symbolizing life and blessing. This abundance mirrors God's provision in Genesis 1:20-22 and the blessings of the Messianic kingdom in Amos 9:13-14 and Revelation 22:2.

questions.question: Which places are mentioned as locations from which fishers will stand to spread nets?
options: Engedi and Eneglaim
Jerusalem and Bethlehem
Damascus and Hamath
Zedad and Hethlon
questions.correctAnswer: Engedi and Eneglaim
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:10 mentions Engedi and Eneglaim as places where fishermen will spread nets, indicating the extensive abundance and blessing. This reflects the restoration of Israel and the abundance promised in Joel 4:18 and the new creation in Revelation 22.

questions.question: What will happen to the miry places and marshes along the river?
options: They shall not be healed and shall be given to salt
They shall become fertile fields
They shall be covered with trees
They shall be filled with fresh water
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be healed and shall be given to salt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:11 states the miry places and marshes will remain barren and become salty, symbolizing judgment on some lands, consistent with Genesis 19:24-25 where salt represents desolation, and the curse on the land in Leviticus 26:33.

questions.question: What is the significance of the trees growing by the riverbanks, according to Ezekiel 47?
options: Their leaves shall not fade and their fruit is for food and medicine
They produce only fruit without leaves
They are symbolic of judgment
They will be cut down for timber
questions.correctAnswer: Their leaves shall not fade and their fruit is for food and medicine
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:12 describes trees whose leaves do not fade and whose fruit provides food and medicine, symbolizing eternal life and healing, reflecting Revelation 22:2 where the tree of life yields healing for the nations, and Isaiah 58:11 about flourishing righteousness.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 47, how will the land be inherited among the tribes of Israel?
options: According to the border described, with Joseph receiving two portions
By conquest and military strength
By purchase from neighboring nations
By random allocation without tribal distinction
questions.correctAnswer: According to the border described, with Joseph receiving two portions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:13 declares land division by tribal borders with Joseph getting two portions, affirming God's covenant promises from Genesis 48:5-6 and reinforcing the tribal inheritance principle seen in Numbers 26:52-56.

questions.question: What boundary is described as the northern border of the land in Ezekiel 47?
options: From the great sea by Hethlon to Zedad, Hamath, Berothah, Sibraim, and Hazarhatticon
From the Dead Sea to the Mediterranean
From Jerusalem to the Jordan River
From Egypt to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: From the great sea by Hethlon to Zedad, Hamath, Berothah, Sibraim, and Hazarhatticon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:15-16 details the northern border including these locations, emphasizing God's sovereign determination of Israel's inheritance, consistent with Joshua 13:5-6 and the promise of land boundaries in Deuteronomy 19:8.

questions.question: How is the east side border of the land defined in Ezekiel 47?
options: From Hauran, Damascus, Gilead, to the east sea by Jordan
Along the Nile River
Through the wilderness without specific landmarks
By the Euphrates River only
questions.correctAnswer: From Hauran, Damascus, Gilead, to the east sea by Jordan
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:18 describes the east border including these notable locations, reflecting God's precise and holy allotment of the promised land as in Numbers 34:1-12 and Joshua 1:4.

questions.question: What provision is made for strangers sojourning among the tribes of Israel in Ezekiel 47?
options: They shall be given inheritance among the tribes as if born in the land
They must leave before inheritance is divided
They receive no inheritance
They must convert to another religion
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be given inheritance among the tribes as if born in the land
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:22-23 promises that strangers living among Israelites will receive inheritance among the tribes, reflecting God’s inclusive covenant community as seen in Leviticus 25:23-34 and the welcoming of Gentiles in Ephesians 2:19.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s restoration is illustrated by the river and its effects in Ezekiel 47?
options: God’s restoration brings life, healing, and abundance to His people
God’s judgment results in destruction and barrenness
God is indifferent to the land’s condition
God’s presence departs from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s restoration brings life, healing, and abundance to His people
questions.explanation: The river’s life-giving properties in Ezekiel 47:1-12 symbolize God’s restoring presence bringing healing and fruitfulness, consistent with Isaiah 35:1-2, John 4:14, and Revelation 21:1-7 where God renews all things.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 47 emphasize the holiness and sanctity of God’s presence?
options: The waters issue from the sanctuary and bring life and healing
The waters cause destruction and death
The sanctuary is left empty and dry
No mention is made of holiness
questions.correctAnswer: The waters issue from the sanctuary and bring life and healing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 47:1 and 12 show the waters come from the sanctuary, indicating God's holy presence as the source of life and healing, reflecting God's holiness in Exodus 15:11 and the life-giving Spirit in John 7:38-39.
